Posts.Title: Homestretch, chin-up fell, what gets you through? chemo072 mccarroll

Posts.Content: lemonpie wrote: Hi everybody, Its been a while since I've posted but as always I'm lurking everyday.  I have a couple of questions hoping for some help.  I'm on Xeloda, 7days on and off  for 7 days, and I'm on Ixempra every 3 weeks.  I have now developed hand/foot syndrome and it is awful.  I can barely walk and my hands look and feel has if they have been scorched.  I can't open doors, button anything. and putting my hands and feet in water is like torture.   I also have "burn" marks on my elbows and behind my knees... After my first round of Xeolda, I'm now on my third cycle, my legs and forearms broke out in a red itchy rash.... the itchyness? finally went away but the red splotchenss is still there and it looks as if its under the skin... Has anyone experienced any of this and if so do you have any words of wisdom????  I tried to call my oncs office but with it being the weekend no luck... recording say's to go to the ER if you feel you need urgent care.... That's the last place I want to go.... Any advice would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks Dx 3/21/2009, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 3/18 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help with chemo side effects lemonpie LinTol

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 07:38AM lemonpie wrote: Thanks for replying... I am holding out hope that with time the pain and stiffness will lessen.  In the mean time I have been soaking my feet and legs in a combination of  epsom salt and Aveeno bath treatments.  Not really sure if its helping but in my desperation for relief I am telling myself that  the epsom salt is drawing the chemicals out of my system and the Aveeno counter acts  the dryness from the salt!!  Dont laugh!!  One thing for sure.. my feet are extremly soft now....  Again thanks so much for replying and best wishes to all.  mmc
Posts.Title: after effects of treatment lemonpie lemonpie

Posts.Content: lemonpie wrote: Hi everyone... I havn't posted in a while..been recouping from sugery and getting prepared for radiation but I would like to hear from others regarding risidual effects of chemo/radiation.  I took 6 rounds of TAC with virtually no problems and then after my last treatment (Aug 2, 2007) my feet, ankles, and calves began to swell and hurt.  I called my ocn nurse and she did not seem too concerned, however, I have really been bothered by this.  The swelling has actually subsided some but my feet and half way up my calves are red and my ankles are stiff as boards.  I have begun to have tingling and sharp pains in my calves and I am thinking that is from neuropothy.... In the mornings I can barely walk and forget walking for any length of time.  HAs anyone else had this problem?  I know it takes awhile for the chemo to get out of the system and I have heard that some people always have some issues regarding the chemo.  I've posted about this before but didn't get much response.  Hoping to hear from others soon....Best wishes to all.   mmc Dx 3/21/2009, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 3/18 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: after effects of treatment lemonpie lemonpie

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 03:29PM lemonpie wrote: Thanks Tamara... I'm sending hubby out for Bag Balm now and thanks Katie for the bump...I'm  going there now...Take care
Posts.Title: Help with chemo side effects lemonpie LinTol

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2008 06:48AM lemonpie wrote: I had Conseco for years and when my husband was diagnosed with liver cancer in 1999 I had a very difficult time getting them to pay. I fought tooth and nail for every claim.  I now have AFLAC and it has been a God send since my diagnoses.  No issues with claims and all my claims have been processed within a couple of weeks.  Good Luck...
Posts.Title: Conseco Supplemental Ins sassyone lemonpie

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2008 08:38AM lemonpie wrote: I had such a difficult experience with Conseco.... my husband died 6 mos after his diagnoses so I did not get to to the point of preventative meds but I will tell you that during his pallative care Conseco did not want to pay for the procedure he had to have done twice weekly to relieve the fluid in his abdomen (although it was a benefit) I finally had to get the docs to write a letter to them explaining the procedure was necessary. I did finally get some compensation but I still feel like I was ripped off in a big way. It seemed like Conseco tried to disprove every claim I made and I had to jump thru hoops to prove the claim was legitimate. Again I wish you luck....
Posts.Title: Conseco Supplemental Ins sassyone lemonpie

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2008 07:27AM lemonpie wrote: Hi Longhorn.... yes TAC was horrible... I will say so far I still have not had anything "worthy" of complaining about with the Carbo/Gemzar.. I just hope its working.... will find out on 6/26....  Keeping my fingers crossed that this IS our magic bullet!!
Posts.Title: Gemzar/Carbo zarowny9 FloridaLady

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2008 10:50AM lemonpie wrote: I'm currently on Gemzar/Carboplatin... just had my 2nd treatment and I have been very lucky.. no horrible side effects yet, I did get a rash on my forearms and upper thighs but it went away after about 2 days.  I have found this combo much much easier to handle than my first experience with TAC.......  I do take my anti-nausea meds as scheduled and overall I feel pretty good....  Wishing you the best.
Posts.Title: Gemzar/Carbo zarowny9 FloridaLady

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 11:08AM lemonpie wrote: Thanks Jule & Pearl for your thoughts.   Jule... glad your scare turned out to be nothing and Snowday, I hope everything turns out ok with you as well.  I know the waiting is the worst part and I'm trying not to worry until I have more info. but it is so hard.... I have one son and 2 small grandchildren who I adore and I cant imagine leaving them behind....  It really bugs me that everything takes so long.    It seems like Apr 2 is a long time to wait.  I guess I have no choice.  Again thanks for replying and I'm wishing you all well... mmc

Posts.Title: so scared lemonpie leaf

Posts.Content: lemonpie wrote: Hi to everyone... although i dont post often I read everyday. I just went for my first 3 month check up after having gone thur Chemo, surg, radiation for Stage 3C, Triple neg IDC.  My blood work came back fine but the mamo on my "good" breast showed a small mass and also an inflamed lymph node.  I go back Apr 2 for biospy, MRI,etc. I'm so scared that its cancer again. My onc would or could not say it was cancer but I have a feeling he knows and just cant tell me until he has the biospy results.  I'm so scared ... I dont think my body could tolerate another round of Chemo. I took 6 rounds of TAC and although I didn't have too many issues with it I feel like its way too soon to do it again.  The swollen lymph node really scares me ... I just need to hear someone tell me something....anything.  Has anyone had another cancer so soon after the first?   I don't like to ask but could sure use some prayers.  Thanks mmc....  Dx 3/21/2009, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 3/18 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 07:36AM lemonpie wrote: I had a hugh problem with my nose running and my eyes watering.  I took 6 rounds of TAC but the waterworks didn't start until the 3rd or 4th treatment and didn't end until a month or two AFTER I completed Chemo.  I really bugs me that that oncs and chemo nurses dont acknowledge all the side effects!!  Stock up on the kleenex... Wishing you the best. Mary
Posts.Title: Taxol and runny/stuff nose??? bluewillow MCBaker

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 01:00PM lemonpie wrote: Hi PattyP, Like you I'm just joining the Stage IV group too.  I am currently doing Xeloda(orally) and Ixempra along with Zometa as an infusion..Had my first infusion about a week ago and felt pretty tired for a couple of days, however, the Xeloda which I take for 7 days and then off for 7 days has given me some problems.  My arms and legs broke out in a very itchy rash and I have had some stomach issues. I just finished my first 7 days and am into my 2nd day of not taking it and I really feel much better.  Hopefully the next round will be better!!   I hope your team comes up with something that will kick that cancer's butt... I will keep you in my prayers.  ((((HUGS))))

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2009 07:01PM lemonpie wrote: I have skull mets.... my diagnoses came when my vision suddenly doubled..  For some reason I didn't even associate my vision problem with the cancer, but lo and behold after a MRI it was revealed that I had many mets to my skull including tumors in both eye orbits,  ribs, and 2 spots on my liver.  I took 2 weeks of radiation to my eyes and I am now on chemo again..  Other than the vision problem I had no other symptoms with the mets to my skull.
Posts.Title: skull mets mreilley mreilley

Posts.Content: May 17, 2009 02:42PM lemonpie wrote: Sher123, Hope you are feeling better today.  Hang in there, it's got to get easier. Well, Ive now done 2 cycles of Xeloda, which I now seem to be tolerating pretty well but just had the second round of Ixempra and Zometa and for a couple of days I felt terrible, nausea, no appitite, not alot of bone pain this time but no energy what so ever.  It's been 5 days since my last treatment and today is the first day I feel almost back to normal...  I seem to want to sleep alot since starting this new combo.

Posts.Title: I'm in the hospital AlaskaDeb spar2

Posts.Content: lemonpie wrote: Hi .... as some of you know I have recently been diagnosed with a second primary in my other breast immediatly following treatment for my first stage 3c diagnoses but I am so confused.  I have had several biopsies on areas in the breast but all come back B9, the cancer is only showing up in one lymph node. I took 5 rounds of paciltaxol(weekly) with no effect and my onc just switched me to gemzar/carboplatin for which I have had one treatment.  My question is I can feel some sort of dull pain under my arm where the lymph node is and was wondering what that means.  I never felt anything with my first cancer and I had a very large tumor (8.5cm) with at least 3 positive lymph nodes.  This new cancer is triple positive (old one was trip neg.) I see the onc next week and everytime I see him he seems very optimistic but I'm wondering if anyone has any ideas... is the pain I feel mean the treatment is working or could it be that the lymph node is getting bigger.. Also, I wonder if I'm getting the right treatment combo for trip positive.  I thought the carboplatin was for negs...  Thanks for any input or thoughts on my situation.  Dx 3/21/2009, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, 3/18 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: recurrance in lymph node lemonpie vhqh

Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 02:31PM lemonpie wrote: Thanks mimi for your concern. I do plan on asking about Herceptin and thanks Tender for the advice... with the first cancer i was so consumed with getting all the information I could about trip negs that I spent most of my waking hours researching but with this new one I feel so out of sorts.  I'm so discouraged with MDA but yet I've always felt like they were the best in the world.  I cant understand how I can have breast cancer in a lymph node but the cancer in the breast cant be found,not to mention getting a recourence so soon.  Thanks again for the advice.
Posts.Title: recurrance in lymph node lemonpie vhqh

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2008 05:59PM lemonpie wrote: Crossing EVERYTHING for you..... good luck with the new plan
Posts.Title: My New Plan Watson jansdaughter

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 07:48AM lemonpie wrote: Apple/Mary, My name is Mary and I have been lurking around since my original diagnoses in 2007.   I, like you, had a very large tumor 8.5 cm, went thru all the treatment and had an excellent response, surgery (modified radical masectomy), radiation, originally staged at 3C, only to discover swollen lymph nodes on the other side,(3 months after finishing all original treatment), which tested positive for cancer, however, as it turns out the "new" cancer did not have the same pathology as the first.   Anyway, I had to go thru another 6 months of chemo, surgery, radiation but again I had a complete response to the treatment, also I had no other spread of the disease to any organs or bone.   With my original diagnoses I learned all I could about the disease but I really dont know alot about my 2nd cancer and I really dont ask too many questions, however, I suspect one day I will get the urge to know more.  I am being treated at a large very well respected cancer center so I feel like I'm getting the best care possible. Also thru it all I have actually felt well and worked thru most of my treatments.  Your story reminded me of mine and I just want you to know that although it was very difficult to realize that I had to do it all again....I did it and came out on the other side and so can you.   I wish you the best and will keep you in my prayers.

I'm great.  He says " you're looking alot better now, there for a while you really looked bad, your skin had a funny grey color too it....glad to see your doing better.....my reply......  ugh......thanks?????    Anyway, just needed to get that off my chest!!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 09:47AM lemonpie wrote: In my situation.....there were 7 rad oncs in the breast clinic and of the 7 three felt that I did not need rads (one of those being my doc) and 4 felt like I should have it so the decision was left to me.  I was told that if I did not have the rads there was an 85% chance of NOT having a recurrance and if I DID have rads 97% chance of NO recurrance.  I chose to have it.
Posts.Title: What % would make you do it? Estepp Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 10:31AM lemonpie wrote: Wow... If I were you I would report her to the charge nurse. I went in to have my port flushed once and the nurse that was there was very rude to me as well, in fact she said she didn't have time to flush everybody's port who just walked in off the street (no appts necessary for port flushes at my clinic). She was upset because it was lunch time and she said she would like to eat like everybody else instead of being stuck there doing port flushes.  I told her that if I had my choice I would rather be the one GIVING the port flush than RECEIVING it but to have a nice day in spite of it all!!  She shut up and did her job!!   I hope you report her, people with that attitiude shoud find another profession.....

Posts.Title: Mets to eye orbit lemonpie pitanga

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2007 01:23AM lemonpie wrote: I am still having problems with my feet and legs and I finished Chemo (TAC) in August. I took 6 rounds of TAC and did not have any feet/leg problems until the 5th round.  My ankles swell making it hard to walk (it's worse in the morning & when I sit for a while).  The bottoms of my feet burn sometimes and my toe nails (big toes) are discolored.  I also get sharp pains in my feet & calves.  I dont have a real problem with numbness although a couple of weeks ago three fingers on my left hand started tingling and are now numb from time to time.  It is slowly getting better and I am just hoping that with time all of this will go away.  I know sometimes it doesn't but I am hoping for the best.  Good luck to all....
Posts.Title: Chemo Side Effects with Feet and Mouth Sores Dollbaby63 lornasgrandma2000

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 03:13PM lemonpie wrote: Hi Linda, March is the dreaded month for me as well.  Like you, I am coming up on the 2nd anniversary of my first cancer (march 7) and the 1st anniversary of the second cancer (march 12). It has been a whirlwind nightmare for me as well... 2 mastectomies, 6 mos of TAC for the first cancer then another 5 mos of chemo (Gemzar & Carboplatin) for the 2nd one, radiation on both sides, I however, tested negative for BRAC2.   I've also  joined the gym trying to shed the 30 lbs I gained thru it all and I try to eat a diet full of veggies and fruit but most importantly I plan for the future and I keep myself busy with work, grandkids, and hobbies.....but with March approaching I am also finding it difficult to stay focused. I'm anxious to hear how others get through those anniversaries....  Good Luck... I will say a prayer for you....

Wishing you the best..
